grammar.title: Preterite Tense (Regular Verbs)
grammar.explanation: The preterite tense is used to describe completed actions in the past. For -AR verbs, remove -ar and add: -é, -aste, -ó, -amos, -asteis, -aron. For -ER/-IR verbs, remove the ending and add: -í, -iste, -ió, -imos, -isteis, -ieron.

examples.translation: Yesterday I talked with my mother.
We ate pizza last night.
She wrote a letter.

patterns: hablar → hablé, hablaste, habló, hablamos, hablasteis, hablaron
comer → comí, comiste, comió, comimos, comisteis, comieron
vivir → viví, viviste, vivió, vivimos, vivisteis, vivieron

grammar.title: Imperfect Tense
grammar.explanation: The imperfect tense describes ongoing or habitual actions in the past, background descriptions, and actions without a specific endpoint. For -AR verbs: -aba, -abas, -aba, -ábamos, -abais, -aban. For -ER/-IR verbs: -ía, -ías, -ía, -íamos, -íais, -ían.

examples.sentence: Cuando era niño, jugaba en el parque.
examples.translation: When I was a child, I used to play in the park.
While I was studying, I was listening to music.

examples.sentence: Hacía sol y los pájaros cantaban.
examples.translation: It was sunny and the birds were singing.

patterns: hablar → hablaba, hablabas, hablaba, hablábamos, hablabais, hablaban
comer → comía, comías, comía, comíamos, comíais, comían
vivir → vivía, vivías, vivía, vivíamos, vivíais, vivían

grammar.title: Preterite vs Imperfect
grammar.explanation: The preterite is used for completed, one-time actions with a clear beginning or end. The imperfect is used for ongoing states, habitual past actions, and background descriptions. Often both tenses are used together: imperfect for background, preterite for the main action.

examples.translation: It was raining when I left home.
While I was sleeping, the phone rang.
It was late and I was tired.

exercises.question: Cuando ___ (ser) niño, siempre ___ (ir) a la playa.

grammar.title: Comparatives
grammar.explanation: To compare two things: más/menos + adjective + que (more/less than). Some adjectives have irregular comparatives: bueno → mejor, malo → peor, grande → mayor, pequeño → menor. For equality: tan + adjective + como (as ... as).

examples.sentence: María es más alta que Pedro.
examples.translation: María is taller than Pedro.

examples.sentence: Este libro es menos interesante que el otro.
examples.translation: This book is less interesting than the other one.

examples.sentence: Mi hermano es tan inteligente como yo.
examples.translation: My brother is as intelligent as me.

exercises.question: Este restaurante es ___ que el otro.

grammar.title: Future Tense (Simple)
grammar.explanation: The simple future is formed by adding these endings to the infinitive: -é, -ás, -á, -emos, -éis, -án. It expresses future actions, predictions, and probability. Some verbs have irregular stems: tener → tendr-, poder → podr-, hacer → har-, decir → dir-, salir → saldr-.

examples.translation: Tomorrow I will go to the cinema.
Will you come to the party?

examples.sentence: El año que viene viajaremos a España.
examples.translation: Next year we will travel to Spain.

patterns: hablar → hablaré, hablarás, hablará, hablaremos, hablaréis, hablarán
comer → comeré, comerás, comerá, comeremos, comeréis, comerán
tener → tendré, poder → podré, hacer → haré

grammar.title: Reflexive Verbs
grammar.explanation: Reflexive verbs indicate that the subject performs an action on itself. They use reflexive pronouns: me, te, se, nos, os, se. Many daily routine verbs are reflexive: levantarse, ducharse, vestirse, acostarse, lavarse, peinarse.

examples.translation: I get up at seven.
What time do you go to bed?

examples.sentence: Ella se maquilla por la mañana.
examples.translation: She puts on makeup in the morning.

grammar.title: Direct Object Pronouns
grammar.explanation: Direct object pronouns replace the noun receiving the action: me (me), te (you), lo/la (him/her/it/you formal), nos (us), os (you all), los/las (them/you all). They are placed before the conjugated verb or attached to infinitives and gerunds.

examples.translation: Do you have the book? Yes, I have it.
Do you know María? Yes, I know her.
I'm going to buy it tomorrow.

grammar.title: Indirect Object Pronouns
grammar.explanation: Indirect object pronouns indicate to whom or for whom an action is done: me (to me), te (to you), le (to him/her/you formal), nos (to us), os (to you all), les (to them/you all). They are placed before the verb and often used with verbs like dar, decir, escribir, enviar.

examples.sentence: Le di el libro a Juan.
examples.translation: I gave the book to Juan.
Can you help me?
They sent us a letter.

exercises.question: ___ escribí una carta a mi amigo.

grammar.title: Conditional Tense
grammar.explanation: The conditional expresses what would happen, polite requests, and hypothetical situations. It is formed by adding -ía, -ías, -ía, -íamos, -íais, -ían to the infinitive. Verbs with irregular future stems use the same irregular stem for conditional.

examples.sentence: Me gustaría un café, por favor.
examples.translation: I would like a coffee, please.
Could you help me?
If I had time, I would travel more.

patterns: hablar → hablaría, hablarías, hablaría, hablaríamos, hablaríais, hablarían
comer → comería, comerías, comería, comeríamos, comeríais, comerían
tener → tendría, poder → podría, hacer → haría

grammar.title: Ir a + Infinitive (Near Future)
grammar.explanation: The construction 'ir a + infinitive' expresses future plans and intentions, similar to 'going to' in English. It is very common in spoken Spanish and is formed with the present tense of ir (voy, vas, va, vamos, vais, van) + a + infinitive.

examples.translation: I'm going to study tonight.
What are you going to do tomorrow?

examples.sentence: Vamos a comer en un restaurante.
examples.translation: We're going to eat at a restaurant.

exercises.question: Mañana ___ a visitar a mis abuelos.
